ABSTRACT
HUSSAIN, S. M. Simulation of groundwater flow by the analytic element method. 2017. 135 p. Tese (Doutorado em Ciências – Ciências de Computação e Matemática Computacional) – Instituto de Ciências Matemáticas e de Computação, Universidade de São Paulo, São Carlos – SP, 2017.
Groundwater studies face computational limitations when providing local detail within regional models. The researchers are concentrated on applying the numerical models to minimize the difference between the physical reality and the implemented numerical model by considering the minimum computational cost. This work consists of the study of line-elements (such as line-doublets, circles, polygons, fractures) using the Analytic Element Method (AEM) for groundwater flow. In this work, we consider the study of two-dimensional groundwater flow in fractured porous media by the Analytic Element Method. We develop a numerical solution based on a series expansion for a problem with more than one fracture. Each fracture has an influence that can be expanded in a series that satisfies Laplace’s equation exactly. In the series expansion, the unknown coefficients are obtained from the discharge potentials of all other elements that are related to the expansion coefficients. Sizes, locations and conductivities for all inhomogeneities are selected arbitrarily. This work also discusses a matrix method obtained by imposing the intern boundary conditions for the Analytic Element Method. The convergence analysis of a Gauss-Seidel type iterative method is also discussed.
Keywords: Analytic Element Method, Fractures, Groundwater Flow, Matrix Method, Numerical Simulations.
RESUMO
HUSSAIN, S. M. Simulação do escoamento de água subterrânea pelo método de elemento analítico. 2017. 135 p. Tese (Doutorado em Ciências – Ciências de Computação e Matemática Computacional) – Instituto de Ciências Matemáticas e de Computação, Universidade de São Paulo, São Carlos – SP, 2017.
Estudos de águas subterrâneas enfrentam limitações computacionais ao fornecer detalhes locais em modelos regionais. Os pesquisadores estão concentrados na aplicação dos modelos numé- ricos para minimizar a diferença entre a realidade física e o modelo numérico implementado considerando o custo computacional mínimo. Este trabalho consiste no estudo de elementos de linha (como line-doublets, círculos, polígonos, fraturas) usando o Método de Elemento Analítico (AEM) para o fluxo de águas subterrâneas. Neste trabalho, consideramos o estudo do fluxo bidimensional de águas subterrâneas em meios porosos fraturados pelo Método dos Elementos Analíticos. Desenvolvemos uma solução numérica baseada em uma expansão em série para um problema com mais de uma fratura. Cada fratura tem uma influência que pode ser expandida em uma série que satisfaça exatamente a equação de Laplace. Na expansão da série, os coeficientes desconhecidos são obtidos a partir dos potenciais de descarga de todos os outros elementos que estão relacionados aos coeficientes de expansão. Tamanhos, locais e condutividades para todas as não-homogeneidades são arbitrariamente selecionados. Este trabalho também discute o método da matriz obtido impondo as condições de contorno do interno para o Método do Elemento Analítico. A análise de convergência de um método iterativo tipo Gauss-Seidel também é discutida.
Palavras-chave: Método do Elemento Analítico, Fracturas, Escoamento de Águas Subterrâneas, Método da Matrix, Simulações Numéricas.

1 INTRODUCTION
The Analytic Element Method (AEM) was developed by Otto D. L. Strack in 1989, it is a numerical method used for the solution of partial differential equations modelling groundwater problems. The method is based on the principle of superposition. It uses the exact solution of the governing equations for basic fundamental features of the aquifer, such as a well, a river, an impermeable barrier, a sink, called Analytic Elements, and combines such solutions by superposition to approximate the solution of a much more complex real problem. The solutions to the governing equation obtained by AEM will be exact, but the boundary conditions will be satisfied only approximately. It does not require the specific domain to be discretized giving rise to a grid, only the boundary conditions at infinity and the internal conditions at certain points are required (MARIN, 2011).
Problems in groundwater flow have been an area of active research for the past few decades. Researchers working in these areas strived along the years for developing different numerical methods using the governing equations of the physical phenomena (MARIN, 2011; STRACK, 1989; HAITJEMA, 1995). To model groundwater systems, mathematical representa- tions are used. Modelling plays an important role, and is the most effective method to make such estimations involving complexities and uncertainties which model the behaviour of the aquifer. Numerical modelling is a practical tool for understanding complex phenomena and obtaining information. The implementation of the numerical models is usually made on a computer, that can lead to errors, such as truncation and approximation. In recent years, researchers concen- trated on developing numerical models with low computational cost for the required problems minimizing the difference between the physical reality and the implemented numerical model (MARIN, 2011). However, one of the major difficulties to be overcome in flow of groundwater is the problem of fractures, that has received much attention.
The problem of fractured media is complex, and difficult to obtain experimental data (MARIN, 2011; STRACK, 1989). Usual groundwater simulation codes use finite element and finite difference methods, which though capable of simulating fracture flow phenomena, suffers
30 Chapter 1. Introduction
from drawbacks such as difficulties with scale differences, dependence on domain discretization, mesh generation and solution approximations (WENDLAND; HIMMELSBACH, 2002). We shall introduce the Analytic Element Method which is more suitable for solving the problems of large aquifers due to computational costs.
The main objective of this work is to study AEM for an array of fractures and other elements like line-doublets, circular inhomogeneities. The numerical solution is based on series expansion for the solution that satisfy the governing equation exactly. The principle of superposi- tion is then used to linearly combine the solutions with unknown coefficients. These coefficients are then found by solving a linear system. The study of efficient numerical methods for solving the linear system and the convergence analysis of a Gauss-Seidel type iterative method are the main contributions of this work.
This work is organized as follows: Chapter 2 consists of some basic concepts for obtaining the governing equations. Chapter 3 consists of the methodology for solving the problems that is based on the Analytic Element Method. Chapter 4 consists of the problems of circular inhomogeneities. Chapter 5 consists of the problems of fractures. Chapter 6 consists of the problems of polygonal inhomogeneities formed by line-elements called line-doublets and their comparison with the exact solutions of a circular inhomogeneity and a fracture. Chapter 7 consists of solution algorithm. Chapter 8 consists of results and its discussion. Chapter 9 consists of conclusion and Chapter 10 consists of future work.

3 ANALYTIC ELEMENT METHOD
This chapter describes a brief description of the Analytic Element Method, which is based on (STRACK, 1989; MARIN, 2011).
3.1 Introduction
The Analytic Element Method (AEM) was presented by Otto D.L. Strack to simulate groundwater flow. It uses the exact solution of the governing equations for basic fundamental features of the aquifer, such as a well, a river, an impermeable barrier, a sink, called Analytic Elements, and combines such solutions by superposition to approximate the solution of a much more complex real problem. The AEM is based on analytic solutions of the groundwater gov- erning equations and does not depend on domain discretization, being able to tackle multiscale problems where other methods have difficulties (MARIN, 2011; STRACK, 1989). This method has been applied in different fields such as wellhead protection area delineation, nuclear waste repositories, and vertical stratified aquifers (MARIN, 2011; WONG; CRAIG, 2010). In this method, each analytic solution represents an hydrogeologic feature. The hydrogeologic feature is discretized into simpler geometric features, like points, line segments or polygons. Each geomet- ric feature is represented by an analytic function with unknown coefficients. The free coefficients on these functions must be calculated to satisfy the boundary conditions imposed. In one of the solution approaches, the coefficients are found by specifying the boundary conditions for the coordinate points on the elements, using the collocation method. There are several approaches to improve the numerical accuracy or decrease the computational time required to solve the resulting system of equations (BAKKER, 2008; BAKKER et al., 1999; BAKKER; KELSON, 2009; BANDILLA; RABIDEAU; JANKOVIC?, 2009; JANKOVIC?; BARNES, 1999b). In recent years, AEM received attention with its use for harmonically heterogeneous aquifers (CRAIG, 2009), and the use of Wirtinger calculus (STRACK, 2009a; STRACK, 2009b). Recently, Strack (STRACK, 2014) used the Cauchy Integral formula combined with the Joukowsky transform

to satisfy the boundary conditions for circular inhomogeneities and line-doublets. Readers are encouraged to read (BARNES; JANKOVIC?, 1999) for an introductory level discussion of the AEM.

5 FRACTURES
This chapter deals with the problems of fractures in an uniform flow field and methodol- ogy for solving it. The proposed methodology is based on the Analytic Element Method (AEM) described in (STRACK, 1982; MARIN, 2011).
5.1 Introduction
Simulation of groundwater flow in fractured porous media is a relevant problem in different fields such as geologic repositories for nuclear wastes and groundwater contamination (BERKOWITZ, 2002; NEUMAN, 2005). Groundwater flow in fractures is fundamental in this context. It is usually present in almost all geologic formations, and can propagate groundwater (and solutes) several orders of magnitude faster than the porous media, being a contamination vector (BERKOWITZ, 2002). Geometry of a fracture is a key factor in the process occurring in it. One of the basic principle is that the fracture would have an ellipsoid shape with no flow at the ends. Fractures are usually thin and saturated with water. The walls of the fractures are symmetric with respect to the planes through the centres of the fractures. The most common conceptual model is that the fracture is formed by smooth and flat parallel plates, as considered for various experiments in different woks (MARIN, 2011; BERKOWITZ, 2002; BEAR; TSANG; MARSILY, 2012; WENDLAND; HIMMELSBACH, 2002). In general, there are two common classes to model flow in fracture networks:
5.1.1 Continuous Models
Continuous models consists of two or more continuous interacting fractures. It is applied when a continuous network of fractures is highly connected and dense, whereas, the porous medium can be ignored. In most cases it is complicated to assume a continuous model for fractured system (fractals), due to the directional dependence in the flow and the influence of
52 Chapter 5. Fractures
different scales for the properties of fractures for the transport see (MARIN, 2011; NEUMAN, 2005).
5.1.2 Discrete Models
Discrete models allow to describe phenomena that they are able to incorporate explicitly the properties of the individual fracture. These models consider each fracture independently, describing its geometric properties and the interconnection between them (BEAR; TSANG; MARSILY, 2012; MARIN, 2011; BERKOWITZ, 2002). Discrete-shaped fractures can be represented by uni, bi and three-dimensional elements. Parameters such as length, aperture and roughness are assigned to each fracture as presented in (CACAS et al., 1990; SINGHAL; GUPTA, 2010).
Discrete fracture networks are generally generated using statistical distributions based on the properties found in the field, such as orientation, length distribution, position, density, aperture. One of the problem in the use of discrete network is to obtain the data. Experimental data may not be sufficient to determine some of these parameters, for which percentage of fracture actually conduct fluid, although the network appear to be well connected. The computational effort required for the simulation using a discrete network can be large, and simplifications such as the use of parallel plate models can be used to reduce such efforts, despite the various evidences that such an approach is not sufficient to reduce the experimental results for the field or laboratory scale (MARIN, 2011; NEUMAN, 2005; WENDLAND; HIMMELSBACH, 2002; CACAS et al., 1990; BERKOWITZ; SCHER, 1995; BERKOWITZ; SCHER, 1997; CVETKOVIC et al., 2010). Once the discrete network of fractures is generated then the flow in it must be determined. The flow models are dependent on the form of the network, but are generally divided into two classes: one considers that the flow occurs only in the fractures, and the other that there is also the flow in the porous medium. In the first case, since the flow is contained only in the fractures, the flow itself is simplified, and generally given by a linear relationship between the flow rate and the head gradient, with the fracture hydraulic conductivity being the proportionality constant (MARIN, 2011; CACAS et al., 1990).
The permeability in the fractured system is generally much larger than the permeability of the porous medium, which leads the velocity of the fluid in the fractures to be larger and faster carrying to solute. However, delaying effects, solute diffusion and chemical reactions can occur in porous blocks. Thus, interaction effects between the fractured and porous medium may be much more important for transport than the flow as presented in (MARIN, 2011; WILSON et al., 1983; BECKER; SHAPIRO et al., 2000; POTERI, 2009; CROUCH, 1976).
Strack and Jancovic? and Barnes used an Iterative Method to solve the linear systems resulting from the analytic elements presented in (JANKOVIC?; BARNES, 1999a). 7 SOLUTION ALGORITHM
Different strategies have been used to satisfy the boundary conditions in the AEM. The first was the collocation, proposed in (STRACK, 1989; HAITJEMA, 1995). It uses predefined points on the element (such as well, line-doublet, circle, fracture etc.) called collocation points, where the boundary conditions are enforced exactly. Each element has a fixed number of degrees of freedom, denoting the analytic element order: a first order element strength is given by a polynomial expansion of order one, with two degrees of freedom, and has two associated collocation points. A system of equations is constructed requiring that the boundary conditions must be satisfied exactly on the collocation points over the element. For example, given a section of a river with a specified head, it can be modelled using a line-sink element with a given contribution computed in such a way that the discharge potential of all the elements gives the specified head value at the collocation points. This method suffers when applied to high-order elements and has been extensively discussed in the literature, see (STRACK, 1989; HAITJEMA, 1995; BARNES; JANKOVIC?, 1999; BATISTA, 2006; NETO; FRANCA, 2008). Later, Strack and Jancovic? and Barnes developed the idea of overspecification, where the number of control points over the element is higher than the number of degrees of freedom for each element, and the boundary conditions are satisfied in a least square sense over the control points presented in (JANKOVIC?; BARNES, 1999a; JANKOVIC?; BARNES, 1999b; BARNES; JANKOVIC?, 1999). They used an Iterative Method to solve the linear systems resulting from the analytic elements see (JANKOVIC?; BARNES, 1999a). This method has the advantage that no matrix needs to be constructed explicitly, saving computer memory. In general fast convergence is achieved for the most types of elements using this method, with high order elements (up to 75) and a relative low overspecification fold. We use the same methodology for solving different problems like circular inhomogeneities, polygonal inhomogeneities formed by line-doublets and fractures. However, we found some cases where the Iterative Method did not converge, like the flow field with many fractures (MARIN; WENDLAND; STRACK, 2012; MARIN, 2011). This motivate us to develop the Matrix Method to satisfy the boundary conditions in this specific problem.

8.2.3 Convergence Analysis
In the simulations presented in Figures 30 to 32, it was observed that the Iterative Method diverged. The Matrix Method, using a direct solver, managed to find a suitable solution for the flow field for a system of fractures. Following the observed behaviour a convergence analysis has been done by the criteria presented in subsection 7.2.3 in this work.
8.2.3.1 Increasing Fracture Hydraulic Conductivity
In order to evaluate the matrix eigenvalues, 3 different geometries of fracture systems in uniform flow were evaluated. These geometries were randomly distributed fractures (geometries 1 and 2) as well as parallel oriented fractures (geometry 3). In the first simulation all the fractures have the same hydraulic conductivity K+ = 1000 m/day and width b = 0.01 m. The background aquifer conductivity is 1 m/day and the uniform flow is along the horizontal direction. In the following simulations the hydraulic conductivity of one fracture (fracture 4 in each geometry) is successively increased.
The maximal eigenvalue obtained for the matrix in each case is presented as a function of the growing factor P, calculated as the product of Pi,n and Gc. Pi,n is defined in eq. (7.17) and Gc is a geometric constant, obtained from the integral function of the fractures, as defined in eq. (7.22).
Figure 34 shows the maximum eigenvalue obtained for the proposed geometries and increasing hydraulic conductivity. The hydraulic conductivity increased from K+ = 102 m/day to K+ = 106 m/day only for one fracture. In the first case, P = 5 × 10?2; whereas for the last one P = 5 × 102.
The analysis of the eigenvalues of the matrix G, presented in subsection 7.2.3, shows that the maximum eigenvalue becomes larger than 1, even in the first case for geometry 2. This is the reason for convergence failure of the Iterative Method.
Figure 34 also shows that all the systems depend on the internal hydraulic conductivities as well as the orientations of the fractures.

8.4 Computational Performance
Different problems such as circular inhomogeneities, polygonal inhomogeneities and fractures were solved by the AEM to compare the processing time for both the Iterative and the Matrix Method. In such cases, it is observed that the Iterative Method takes more processing time than the Matrix Method with high order of series expansion using the same systems. In our simulation both the Matrix and the Iterative algorithm codes are shared, with only the difference in the system solver, so the comparison was made using only our solver for both cases.
Some comparisons were made between the processing times of both the Iterative and the Matrix Method in this work. Figure 50 illustrate the processing time of both the Iterative and the Matrix Method for the problem consists of 10 circular inhomogeneities as shown in Figure 25, and Figure 51 illustrate the processing time of the Matrix Method (because the Iterative Method did not converge for more than one fracture) for the problem consists of 10 fractures as shown in Figure 32. After simulating the problems, it is noticed that the Matrix Method is much faster than the Iterative Method as illustrated in Figures 50 and 51. This means that the computational cost of the Matrix Method is lower. This is because the Iterative solver takes a large number of steps to satisfy the convergence criterion. The matrix solver needs to fully construct the coefficients matrix in the first step, and then need to solve the system once.

9 CONCLUSION
This work proposes to simulate two-dimensional groundwater flow using the Analytic Element Method. Several problems were simulated and described in detail such as: circular inhomogeneities, polygonal inhomogeneities and fractures. All the simulations are programmed in Matlab R2014a and processed on a Core i7 Intel Processor computer.
Circular inhomogeneities were simulated using both the Iterative and the Matrix Method and almost identical results were obtained. The agreement of the numerical solution with the exact solution was excellent, with relative error smaller than machine precision. The complex potential for circular inhomogeneities as well as the iterative solution are known in the literature (JANKOVIC?, 1997; BARNES; JANKOVIC?, 1999; MARIN, 2011). The implementation and results were compared to the existing literature. The results for circular inhomogeneities served as the basis for the comparison and verification of the polygonal inhomogeneities using line- doublets.
Polygonal inhomogeneities were implemented using line-doublets as analytical elements. The complex potential for the line-doublet and the implementation for the iterative algorithm was based on (JANKOVIC?; BARNES, 1999a; MARIN, 2011). In this case, the numerical solution of a polygonal circular inhomogeneity was compared with the exact solution of a circular inhomogeneity, whereas a polygonal ellipsoidal inhomogeneity using line-doublets was compared with the exact solution of a single fracture as described in (STRACK, 1982). Such comparisons were found excellent with satisfactory results. All the systems resulting from line-doublets were solved by both the Iterative and the Matrix Method and almost identical results were obtained.
The complex potential for a discrete fracture system in porous medium was developed in this work, based on the exact solution for one single fracture (STRACK, 1982). This complex potential for one fracture was analysed and implemented by both the Iterative and the Matrix Method and the agreement of the numerical solution with the exact solution was found excellent.
114 Chapter 9. Conclusion
However, during simulations it is observed that the Iterative Method did not converge for some cases, as for instance the flow field with many fractures. This fact led to the Matrix Method to solve the linear system.
The main contributions in this work are the development of the Matrix Method and the convergence analysis of the Iterative Method. The Matrix Method was developed by imposing the intern boundary conditions for the Analytic Element Method. This method, using a direct solver, managed to find the correct solutions for the system of fractures. The Matrix Method takes advantage of the results of the Cauchy’s integral, using the orthogonality of the basic functions of the expansion of the analytical elements for the construction of the matrix.
Moreover, the divergence of the Iterative Method motivated the study of the behaviour of the iterative solutions to the proposed problems using Gauss-Seidel partition. The spectral radius of the Iterative system was analysed, and cases were observed where the spectral radius is larger than 1, which indicates that the convergence of the system to an initial solution vector is not guaranteed. The spectral radius being larger than 1 for the Iterative Method indicated non-convergence of some systems, especially in the case of fractures, and cannot be applied to all analytic element methods in all cases.
In general, it is common in numerical simulation and computation that there is a com- promise between memory usage and processing time. The computational cost of the Iterative Method is higher in processing time and less in memory use, whereas in the Matrix Method the inverse occurs. Higher memory usage leads to lower processing costs, and vice versa. This relation was observed in the comparison of the solution of the same problem to the Iterative and the Matrix Method.

10 FUTURE WORK
In this thesis we developed a numerical solution for discrete models of fracture networks, as presented in Chapter 5. In the series expansion, the unknown coefficients are obtained from the discharge potentials of all other elements that are related to the expansion coefficients. The procedure is applied to two-dimensional groundwater flow in fractured porous media by the Analytic Element Method (AEM) and it is observed that the resulting flow field looks correct and resembles the expected streamlines behaviour in all the examined cases. This motivates us to work with more complex problems such as crossing fractures as shown in Figure 52.
In the literature we found some of the formulation for the crossing fractures as presented in (STRACK, 1982). This formulation is modelled by the complex potential of the line-doublets (line-segments). If we follow the method developed in (STRACK, 1982), we need to simulate minimum eight line-doublets to approximate two crossing fractures as shown in Figure 52, which will be computationally costly as observed in this thesis. Thus, we try to generalize the approach presented in this thesis for crossing fractures using the conditions prescribed at the crossing as described in (STRACK, 1982).

D RELATIVE ERROR
D.1 Error Analysis Groundwater flow simulations consists of a set of computational tools designed for
the solution of the governing equations modelling the physical phenomena (MARIN, 2011; GRAND, 2003). The processing of the numerical algorithm is generally made on a computer. Computers due to their limitations have the restriction that they only work with discrete and finite representations of continuous quantities, like mathematical and physical models which may include continuous and discrete quantities. This limitation is one of the origin of the error associated to numerical models (MARIN, 2011; PRESS, 2007). Other source of the error is the truncation error, associated to the numerical model itself. The truncation error arises from the finite quantity of memory of a computer to use of finite series and require to compute discrete quantities of continuous variables (MARIN, 2011; PRESS, 2007). An example of a truncation error is the error that arises when calculating an integral, computing the function to be integrated in a discrete set of points.
There are two ways to calculate the error: the absolute error and the relative error. The absolute error is defined as the magnitude of the difference between the values of the exact and the numerical solution, and is given by:
Absoluteerror = ? abs(Exactsolution(xi)? Numericalsolution(xi)). (D.1)
The relative error is defined as the absolute error divided by the magnitude of the exact value for defined points, and is given by:
Relativeerror = ? abs (
Exactsolution(xi)? Numericalsolution(xi) Exactsolution(xi)
) . (D.2)
Mapping of error values are obtained by evaluating the absolute and the relative error for the control points of the given domain. For each point of the domain, the absolute or relative error is calculated and the results plot by the graphs.
